captions.text: Did You Know? The Japanese title for the Earthbound series, Mother, was inspired by a song of the same name by John Lennon.
The lyrics of "Mother" deal with Lennon's experience of growing up without a father.
Earthbound creator Shigesato Itoi chose this name for his project because his own father was absent through much of his life.
This theme is addressed in the first two Mother games, in which the main protagonist's father is never seen and only makes an appearance as a voice on a telephone.
Itoi also felt the title of "Mother" was especially fitting as this game series is more feminine than other RPGs.
The Earthbound series is famous for combining colorful graphics and silly dialog with dark and sometimes depressing themes.
These themes have roots in the work of some of Itoi's favorite authors, including Stephen King and Kurt Vonnegut.
Both known for science fiction and satire respectively.
Earthbound's strange alien creatures referred to as "Mr. Saturn" were inspired by Kurt Vonnegut's Tralfamadorians.
A species of silly looking benign aliens that appear in Kurt Vonnegut's novels.
In the game, the speech of Mr. Saturn is represented by an unusual font.
In both the Japanese and English versions.
The Japanese font was designed by Itoi himself and was based on his daughters handwriting at the time.
According to Mr. Itoi, the Mr Saturn race are the symbolism for innocence in the game.
Before creating Earthbound, Itoi had worked for Nintendo as a copywriter, designing catchy taglines for their games.
He had also done similar work with the prominent Japanese animation company Studio Ghibli.
He also voiced the father in My Neighbor Totoro, and had become a minor celebrity by the time he began work on video games.
When Itoi initially proposed Mother to Shigeru Miyamoto, Miyamoto's reactions reportedly made Itoi cry.
In 2008 Itoi posted on his blog:
It is often speculated that Miyamoto's hesitation was due to Nintendo's history of greenlighting low-quality Famicom games simply because they involved celebrity figures.
However Nintendo president Hiroshi Yamauchi was a big fan of Itoi's work within the company and Mother was approved for production.
Miyamoto's opinion changed after the release of the game and he later admitted in an interview that Mother was the first RPG he ever completed on his own.
And that he even restarted from the beginning after losing his save file.
It's become known that a fully translated and localized version of the first Mother game was produced by Nintendo of America, but it was canceled before its release.
In July 1998, a group of fans found a prototype cartridge of the English version of Mother and circulated the game's ROM online.
Many fans were surprised to learn how much had been changed between the Japanese and American versions of the game.
This included additional configuration menus, detailed enemy descriptions, new and redesigned areas on the map, and an added "run" ability.
Some of these changes were added by request of Nintendo of America's Earthbound producer and script-writer, Phil Sandhop.
Sandhop stated that there were plans to release the game with an enhanced 80-page instruction manual, and even a separate release of the game's soundtrack.
The game was ultimately canceled because in addition to the cost of all the extra material, the cartridge itself was too expensive due to the size and scope of the game.
It required extra memory and a battery for saving, which made it too costly to produce and market at the time.
This was partly due to Nintendo of America preparing to launch the Super Nintendo.
Prior to the cancellation, several magazines had printed small previews of the NES release of Mother, already renamed "Earthbound".
Its not known why Nintendo of America renamed the game, and Nintendo has never officially commented on the matter.
It's possible the game wasn't originally planned to be renamed at all.
Listings in the United States Patent and Trademark Offices show Nintendo of America first trademarking the name "Mother" in November 1989.
The name "Earth Bound" wasn't registered until August 1990.
Interestingly enough, the name "Space Bound" was also registered.
It's possible this name went unused in order to not mislead players into thinking the game featured space travel or combat.
Despite the fact that the first game in the Earthbound series was never released outside of Japan,
the process of working on the localization was an important turning point in Nintendo's history.
In an interview with lostlevels.org, Phil Sandhop explained,
Nintendo of Japan would typically work on a game even after it was released in their region in order to conform with Nintendo of America's strict guidelines for age-appropriate content.
Because of the change in procedure at Japan, by the time Earthbound for the Super Nintendo was localized for other territories much less work had to be done.
However, there are still many interesting differences between Earthbound and Mother 2.
In Mother 2, the text above various stores in the game reads "Drug".
In Earthbound most of this text was altered to spell "Shop" instead.
Early in the game when Pokey and Picky get in trouble for being out so late, Mother 2 uses a sound effect that sounds as if their father is beating them.
In Earthbound this sound effect was changed to resemble loud yelling.
The town of Fourside has a bar in Mother 2, and the people inside the bar are found to be drinking alcohol.
In Earthbound, this bar was changed to a Cafe and the customers all refer to their drinks as Coffee or Espresso.
Almost all religious references and cross shapes were removed in Earthbound.
Even the red crosses on hospitals and the nurses uniforms were removed, despite not having anything to do with religion.
They were actually removed due to the red cross being a copyrighted trademark for the Red Cross charity.
Another alteration in the English translation is of the Insane Cultist enemies from Happy Happy Village.
In Mother 2 the letters "HH" can be seen on the forehead of their masks.
This was removed in Earthbound and a pompom similar to Santa's hat was added to the tip of the pointy masks.
Presumably to distance the design from any resemblance to the Ku Klux Klan.
In the segment of Earthbound where Ness enters his own subconscious, he can be seen wearing pajamas.
In Mother 2, Ness is naked, wearing nothing but his hat.
One of the most obvious differences between Mother 2 and Earthbound is of the pencil statues that block access to certain areas in the game.
In Mother 2 these statues depict an octopus rather than a pencil.
In an interview, Shigesato Itoi explained the reason for the octopus statues.
He said that in times when the player doesn't know what to do, and he or she feels all clogged in the head, "it's as if an octopus is blocking the way."
In Mother 2 the player is given The Octopus Eraser Machine to destroy the obstacle.
In Earthbound the player receives The Pencil Eraser to clear the way.
Another statue blocking a path in Earthbound is of a pencil eraser, which requires the Eraser Eraser to clear off.
In Mother 2, this statue depicts a limbless doll.
The reason for this is a play on words.
In Japanese, dolls are called "kokeshi", and the word for eraser is "keshi".
So the item that clears the path is the "kokeshi keshi".
Not all changes between the two versions were cut content.
In Mother 2, a sign can be found posted in the town of Threed by a parental organization which warns against playing video games for over 2 hours straight.
In Earthbound, this organization is given the name "Parents Opposing Obsession Plan".
Which as an acronym spells out "poop".
No equivalent reference is known to exist in the original version.
